div.head: Robert Corsellton Will
div.p:
In the name of God Amen. The sixth day of January
one thousand six hundred seventy and four I Robert Corsellton of
Charles County in the provinence of Maryland being sick and weake in
body but of good and perfect memory thanks bee to God knowing
that I am naturally Borne and ordained to die and considering the
uncertaintee of this life on earth doe make this my last will and
testament in manner and form following first I bequeath my soule
and I peritt into the hands of almighty God my heavenly father by whome
of his mure grace and favour I trust to be reveived into eternal rest through
the
the Death of my sweet saviour Jesus Christ in whose precious blood
I set the only hope of my satuatione my wreched body in hope of
a Joyfull resurection I commit to the earth to be decently buried by
my Executors hereafter named and touching the distruition of my
mortal goods, I disphose as followeth. First I will that all my
Just Debts shall be honestly paid.
Item I make Constitute and appoint Mary my wife my sole Executor

Item. I give and bequeath unto my sonne Robert one hundred and fifty
acres of land called York if said son Robert shall due without an
heir then the said land shall fall to my sonne John if my sone John
shall dye without heir then the said land shall fall to my Daughter
Mary and her heirs forever.

Item I give and bequeath to my sone John after the Decease of Mary my wife
my plantation and land called Naping if my sone John should
die without an heir then the said land and plantation shall fall
to my sone Robert if my son Robert shall dye without heirs then the
said land plantation shall fall unto my Daughter Mary and her heris
forever Lastlt I doe make and appoint my said children and their Estates
untill they come to age and I doe utterly revoke all wills by me fornesly
made either by word or writing and declare this to be my last will
and testament in witness hereof I have hereunto set my hand and seal

Signed Sealed and Delivered
In the presense of us
Thomas Jenkins - George Longham
his
Robert Corsellton
mark

On the back of the aforegoing will was Endorsed the foll. probate
May 21st. 1678 Then was this will proved in common form
by the oaths of George Longham and Thomas Jenkins witnesses to
the same - before me
4 1/4 sides
Benjamin Rozer
